title: Heraclas of Alexandria
description: Bishop of Alexandria. Known for his role in the early catechetical school and his influence on Origen.

title: Ambrose of Alexandria
description: Early Christian presbyter and scholar, known for his mentorship of Origen and influence on Alexandrian Christianity.

title: Ammonius of Alexandria
description: Christian philosopher, considered one of the founders of the Alexandrian School of theology. He influenced Origen but little of his own work survives.

title: Dionysius of Alexandria
description: Bishop of Alexandria, known for his letters dealing with theological and ecclesiastical issues, including the Novatian controversy and Arianism.

title: Pierius of Alexandria
description: Known as "Origen Junior" for his eloquence and theological writings. He was a presbyter in Alexandria and known for his sermons and theological studies.

title: Anatolius of Alexandria
description: Christian philosopher, bishop, and mathematician. Known for his contributions to the Alexandrian Church and early Christian chronology.

title: Theonas of Alexandria
description: Bishop of Alexandria, known for his letters and his leadership during the Diocletian persecution.

title: Peter of Alexandria
description: Bishop and theologian, known for his opposition to Arianism and his writings on church discipline. His Canonical Epistle deals with penance.

title: Peter of Alexandria
description: Bishop of Alexandria known for his opposition to Arianism and his letters on church discipline during times of persecution. He was martyred in 311 AD.

title: Alexander of Alexandria
description: Bishop of Alexandria, a central figure in the early Arian controversy. He is known for his theological defense of the divinity of Christ.

title: Marcellus of Ancyra
description: Bishop of Ancyra, known for his opposition to Arianism. His teachings were controversial and led to his temporary excommunication.

title: Theophilus of Antioch
description: Bishop of Antioch, best known for his work To Autolycus, an apologetic defense of Christianity.

title: Serapion of Antioch
description: Bishop of Antioch, known for his writings against Montanism and his emphasis on the authority of the canonical Gospels.

title: Paul of Samosata
description: Bishop of Antioch, known for his heretical views on the nature of Christ (adoptionism) and his role in the early Arian controversy. Condemned at a synod in Antioch.

title: Malchion of Antioch
description: Christian presbyter and scholar, known for his refutation of Paul of Samosata, whose views on Christology were considered heretical.

title: Malchion of Antioch
description: Christian presbyter and philosopher, known for his theological disputes with Paul of Samosata and his defense of orthodox Christology.

title: Lucian of Antioch
description: A presbyter and martyr, known for his work on textual criticism of the Bible and for founding the Antiochene School of theology. His theological positions influenced Arianism.

title: Gregory the Illuminator
description: Known for converting Armenia to Christianity and establishing the Armenian Church. Though most of his works are lost, his influence on early Christianity in Armenia was immense.

title: Apelles
description: A disciple of Marcion who later broke away and developed his own theology. While considered heretical by orthodox Christians, he contributed to early theological debates.

title: Rhodo
description: A student of Tatian, known for his polemic writings against the Marcionites and other heretical groups. His works are cited by Eusebius.

title: Musanus
description: Early Christian apologist, known for writing against the Encratites, a sect that promoted extreme asceticism and rejected marriage.

title: Beryllus of Bostra
description: Bishop of Bostra, initially a supporter of a heretical view that denied the pre-existence of Christ. He was corrected by Origen and later accepted orthodox doctrine.

title: Pamphilus of Caesarea
description: Early Christian scholar and martyr, known for his friendship with Eusebius and for his efforts to preserve and promote the writings of Origen.

title: Firmilian of Caesarea
description: Bishop of Caesarea, known for his correspondence with Cyprian and his role in baptism controversies. His letters, preserved by Cyprian, reveal early ecclesiastical thought.

title: Thascius Caecilius Cyprianus
description: Known for his work On the Unity of the Church and numerous letters discussing church discipline and persecution.

title: Archelaus
description: Bishop known for Acts of the Disputation with Manes, a polemic against Manichaeism. His writings represent early Christian efforts to refute heresy.

title: Hosius of Cordoba
description: An influential bishop and advisor to Emperor Constantine, known for his role in the Council of Nicaea. He was a defender of orthodoxy against Arianism.

title: Julius Africanus
description: Early Christian historian, known for his Chronographiae, a world chronicle that attempted to date biblical events.

title: Gregory of Elvira
description: Early Spanish bishop and theologian, known for his contributions to Christological debates and opposition to Arianism.

title: Apollonius of Ephesus
description: Apologist and anti-Montanist writer, known for his Acts of Apollonius, a defense of Christianity and an early account of martyrdom.

title: Silvanus of Gaza
description: Early Christian martyr and bishop of Gaza, known for his defense of Christianity during the Diocletian persecution.

title: Abercius of Hierapolis
description: Known for the Inscription of Abercius, which describes his Christian faith and travels. He is considered one of the first Christian epitaph writers.

title: Claudius Apollinaris
description: Early Christian apologist and bishop of Hierapolis. His defense of Christianity against Roman persecution influenced later Christian thought.

title: Apollinaris of Hierapolis
description: Bishop of Hierapolis, known for writing apologies defending Christianity, particularly addressing the persecution of Christians under Emperor Marcus Aurelius.

title: Maximus of Jerusalem
description: Bishop of Jerusalem, known for his defense of orthodox Christianity against Gnostic heresies. His works are referenced by early historians.

title: Alexander of Jerusalem
description: Bishop of Jerusalem, known for his ecclesiastical letters and influence on Origen. Fragments of his letters are preserved by Eusebius.

title: Narcissus of Jerusalem
description: Bishop of Jerusalem, known for his long episcopate and involvement in the Quartodeciman controversy over the date of Easter.

title: Anatolius of Laodicea
description: Bishop and philosopher, known for his work on mathematics and astronomy, as well as theological writings.

title: Church Father
description: Irenaeus of Lyons, an early church father known for his work "Against Heresies" written around 180 AD.

title: Archelaus of Caschar
description: Bishop of Caschar, famous for his Acts of the Disputation with Manes, a refutation of the founder of Manichaeism. His works were instrumental in combating early heresies.

title: Archelaus of Mesopotamia
description: Early Christian bishop known for his disputes with the Manichaean heresy. His polemical work Acts of Archelaus is an important source for understanding early Christian debates with Manichaeism.

title: Aphrahat
description: Early Syriac Christian author, known for his collection of writings known as the Demonstrations, which addressed theological and ethical issues.

title: Gregory Thaumaturgus
description: Bishop known for his work Panegyric to Origen and for his theological writings. He was a student of Origen.

title: Gregory of Neocaesarea (Gregory Thaumaturgus)
description: A bishop and theologian known for his miraculous powers and his theological writings, including Panegyric on Origen and Canonical Epistle.

title: Hermogenes
description: Christian philosopher, known for his work on creation and cosmology. His views on eternal matter were opposed by Tertullian in Against Hermogenes.

title: Sabellius
description: Christian theologian who advanced a non-Trinitarian view later known as Sabellianism (or modalism), which was condemned by the early church as heresy. His works are largely lost.

title: Commodianus
description: Early Christian Latin poet known for his didactic poetry, especially Carmen Apologeticum, which defended Christian beliefs and addressed pagan critiques.

title: Methodius of Olympus
description: Bishop and anti-Origenist writer, known for Banquet of the Ten Virgins, focusing on eschatology and chastity.

title: Victorinus of Pettau
description: Early Christian bishop and author of one of the earliest commentaries on the Book of Revelation. His views were often considered controversial, and he was later martyred.

title: Victor I of Rome
description: The first Latin-speaking pope, known for his role in the Easter controversy (Quartodecimanism) and his efforts to assert Roman primacy.

title: Hippolytus of Rome
description: Early theologian known for his works against heresy, especially Refutation of All Heresies, and his influence on early liturgical practices.

title: Cornelius of Rome
description: Bishop of Rome, known for his leadership during the Novatian controversy, defending the possibility of repentance for the lapsed.

title: Novatian of Rome
description: A presbyter and theologian who wrote on various theological topics, including his treatise On the Trinity. He was later excommunicated for his rigorist stance on lapsed Christians.

title: Novatian
description: Early Roman presbyter and theologian, known for his schismatic movement and his work On the Trinity, defending the divinity of Christ.

title: Melito of Sardis
description: Bishop of Sardis, known for his Peri Pascha (On the Passover) and his defense of Christian orthodoxy.

title: Phileas of Thmuis
description: Bishop of Thmuis, known for his letter defending Christians facing persecution under Diocletian. He was martyred for his faith.

title: The First Epistle of Clement (Clement of Rome)
description: A letter to the church in Corinth, addressing issues of leadership and church order. Historical references within the text suggest a date around AD 96. Manuscript: Codex Alexandrinus (5th century) and other manuscripts

title: The Didache (Teaching of the Twelve Apostles)
description: A manual of church discipline, including teachings on ethics, rituals, and church organization. The content and style of the text, along with historical references, suggest late 1st or early 2nd century. Manuscript:Codex Hierosolymitanus (or Codex H), dated to 1056 AD

title: The Epistle of Barnabas
description: An early Christian work addressing Christian ethics and theology, emphasizing allegorical interpretations of the Old Testament. Internal evidence and thematic elements indicate late 1st or early 2nd century. Manuscript:Codex Sinaiticus (4th century) and other later manuscripts

title: The Epistles of Ignatius of Antioch
description: A series of letters written to various churches, focusing on church unity, hierarchy, and the Eucharist. Historical context places them around AD 110. Manuscript:Various Greek, Latin, and Syriac manuscripts from the 5th century and later

title: The Shepherd of Hermas
description: An apocalyptic text that includes visions, mandates, and parables, emphasizing repentance and discipline. Text's content suggests early to mid-2nd century. Manuscript:Codex Sinaiticus and other fragments

title: The Fragments of Papias
description: Writings on the teachings of Jesus, known from later references, with a focus on oral tradition. Manuscript:

title: Quadratus of Athens
description: Apologist known for his defense of Christianity to Emperor Hadrian. Only fragments survive. Referenced by Eusebius

title: The Epistle of Polycarp to the Philippians
description: A letter addressing Christian conduct and warning against heresies. Content and external references suggest early 2nd century. Manuscript:Greek and Latin versions

title: Aristides of Athens
description: Christian apologist known for his Apology addressed to Emperor Hadrian. Referenced by Eusebius and other early sources situate it in the early 2nd century. Manuscript:Armenian and Syriac versions preserved.

title: Dionysius of Corinth
description: Known for letters to various churches. Citations and historical context indicate mid-2nd century. Manuscript:Preserved in quotations by Eusebius and other Church Father.

title: Hegesippus
description: Chronicler of early church history, noted for his efforts to defend orthodoxy against heresy. Fragments preserved by Eusebius

title: The Writings of Justin Martyr
description: Includes the First Apology, Second Apology, and Dialogue with Trypho, addressing Christian beliefs and defending against pagan criticisms. Historical references and apologetic context date these writings to mid-2nd century. Manuscript:Several Greek manuscripts from the 14th century onwards

title: Apollinaris of Hierapolis
description: Bishop of Hierapolis, known for his apologies defending Christianity under Marcus Aurelius. Referenced by Eusebius and other sources

title: Tatian the Assyrian
description: Known for Oratio ad Graecos, defending Christianity, and for compiling the Diatessaron. Several manuscripts

title: Bardesanes of Edessa
description: Syrian Christian writer addressing free will and opposing Gnostic fatalism in Book of the Laws of Countries.

title: The Writings of Theophilus of Antioch
description: His work, To Autolycus, is an apologetic text defending Christianity and critiquing pagan beliefs. Manuscript:

title: Polycrates of Ephesus
description: Bishop known for letters concerning Easter controversies. Eusebius and others reference him, situating his letters around the late 2nd century. Manuscript:Fragments preserved in Eusebius' Church History.

title: Melito of Sardis
description: Known for fragments of homilies and apologies, especially a Paschal Homily. Cited by early church historians and contextual references place his works in the late 2nd century. Manuscript:Various fragments preserved in later writings.

title: The Writings of Irenaeus of Lyons
description: His major work, Against Heresies, critiques Gnosticism and establishes early Christian doctrine. Historical references to Gnosticism date these writings to late 2nd century. Manuscript:Latin translations and some Greek fragments

title: The Writings of Athenagoras of Athens
description: Includes A Plea for the Christians and On the Resurrection of the Dead, defending Christian beliefs. Manuscript:

title: Minucius Felix
description: Octavius, a dialogue defending Christianity, is an early example of Christian apologetics. Historical context places it in the late 2nd or early 3rd century.

title: Caius of Rome
description: Theologian known for fragments against Montanism. Contextual analysis from references in early Christian writings. Manuscript:Fragments preserved in other works by Eusebius.

title: The Writings of Clement of Alexandria
description: Major works include Exhortation to the Greeks, The Instructor, and Stromata, discussing Christian theology and philosophy. Theological content and references suggest early 3rd century. Manuscript:Greek manuscripts from the 9th century and later

title: The Writings of Tertullian
description: Includes Apology, Against Marcion, and other works addressing heresy, morality, and church practice. Known historical and theological context places them in early 3rd century. Manuscript:Numerous Latin manuscripts from the Middle Ages

title: Julius Africanus
description: Historian known for Chronographiae, a chronicle of world history. Historical context and citations by later historians place him in the early 3rd century. Manuscript:Fragments in later chronicles and citations.

title: Origen of Alexandria
description: Includes On First Principles, Contra Celsum, and extensive biblical commentaries. Well-documented life and works provide precise early to mid-3rd century dating. Manuscript:Greek and Latin manuscripts from the 4th century onward

title: The Writings of Hippolytus of Rome
description: Includes The Refutation of All Heresies and The Apostolic Tradition, focusing on church order and heresy. Manuscript:

title: The Writings of Novatian
description: Notable for On the Trinity, addressing the nature of God and the Church. Manuscript:

title: Commodianus
description: Christian Latin poet, known for Carmen Apologeticum and other works. Linguistic style and thematic content place his works in the mid-3rd century. Manuscript:Latin manuscripts from later periods.

title: The Writings of Gregory Thaumaturgus
description: Includes Oration and Panegyric Addressed to Origen, expressing gratitude and theological insights. Manuscript:

title: The Writings of Cyprian of Carthage
description: Includes On the Unity of the Church, letters, and treatises on church discipline and unity. Historical context situates these works in mid-3rd century. Manuscript:Latin manuscripts from the 4th century onward

title: The Writings of Dionysius of Alexandria
description: Letters and fragments dealing with various theological and pastoral issues. Manuscript:

title: Victorinus of Pettau
description: Known for Commentary on the Apocalypse. Contextual and thematic analysis of his work suggests late 3rd century. Manuscript:Latin manuscripts from the Middle Ages.

title: The Writings of Methodius of Olympus
description: Known for The Banquet of the Ten Virgins, focusing on eschatology and ethics. Manuscript:

title: The Writings of Arnobius of Sicca
description: Includes Against the Heathen, critiquing pagan religion and defending Christianity. Manuscript:

title: The Writings of Lactantius
description: Includes Divine Institutes, addressing Christian doctrine and philosophy. Manuscript:

title: Eusebius of Caesarea
description: Known for Ecclesiastical History, which documents early Christianity up to his time. He was also involved in the debates leading up to the Council of Nicaea and wrote apologetic works defending the faith. His writings are crucial for preserving early Christian history. Wrote Ecclesiastical History, Life of Constantine, Preparation for the Gospel
